did.unittitle: Frederick R. Gardner collection of Robert Lawson

bioghist.p: Robert Lawson (1892-1957) was an American artist and children's book author. He did some illustrations for The Century Magazine in 1919, and in 1922 he produced illustrations for his first book, Little Prince Too Fat. He won the Taylor Arms Prize of the Society of American Etchers in 1931, and was the first person to receive both the Newbery Medal (Rabbit Hill, 1945) and Caldecott Medal (They Were Strong and Good, 1940).

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of drawings, etchings, books, and papers of Robert Lawson collected by Frederick Gardner. Materials include original drawings, book jacket designs, designs for title pages, and chapter heading devices for Ben and Me, The Tough Winter and many other works illustrated (and some written and illustrated) by Robert Lawson. The collection also includes a “dummy” for Munro Leaf’s The Story of Ferdinand and 31 early etchings by Lawson. Papers of Robert Lawson include: correspondence from readers and publishers; newspaper clippings; articles by and about Lawson; typescripts of speeches; biographical sketches; and manuscripts of The Great Wheel, Refugees, Joney, and several shorter works (some unpublished). Other Lawson materials include: greeting and Christmas cards designed by Lawson; advertisements and announcements for books; photographs of Lawson and Marie Abrams Lawson; photo albums of the Lawsons and Rabbit Hill; several copies of Young Wings, a children's book club magazine; and a copy of Frederick Gardner's Robert Lawson on My Shelves. Additional materials in the collection include incoming and some outgoing correspondence of Frederick Gardner, with publishers, collectors, and dealers, related to his collecting of Lawson materials. Margaret G. Otto is a significant correspondent and the collection contains a sales ledger kept by Otto listing sales of Lawson's prints.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
